description: Doc Ido, a doctor and mechanic who lives and works in the hellish, postapocalyptic "Scrapyard", finds the—miraculously preserved—remains of a female cyborg in a junk heap. After he revives and rebuilds her, the preternaturally strong, amnesiac "Gally" begins to forge a life for herself in a world where every day can bring a fight for life. Adapts the first two volumes of the "Battle Angel Alita" manga.

tags.name: Cyberpunk
tags.description: Set in a future of advanced technological and scientific achievements that have resulted in social disorder.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Cyborg
tags.description: Prominently features a human character whose physiological functions are aided or enhanced by artificial means.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

node.description:
Married to [Jaxon C. Lee](https://anilist.co/staff/95871/)
Full name is Amanda Beth Winn-Lee
Resides in Los Angeles. Born in Houston, Texas

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1521695330)

Currently working as a freelancer, having previously worked for [Artland](https://anilist.co/studio/8/) and [D.A.S.T.](https://anilist.co/studio/6255/)

Yuuki graduated from Saitama Prefectural Toda Shoyo High School and has been active in the school's "Manga and Anime Research Interest Club.” He found business in the National Health Insurance but couldn't give up on being an animator, so he left and became an animator instead. Has collaborated with director [Kazuki Akane](https://anilist.co/staff/102416/) many times, including on his most famous work, [The Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/).

He works on doujinshi under the circles The Man in the High Castle and Ubik, both references to the works of American science fiction author Philip K. Dick. The published doujinshi include key animation from his body of work and specially drawn manga. On the other hand, since he worked on Ralphilia Saga by [Akara Arisato](https://anilist.co/staff/149449/), he has been involved in several works as a guest member of the doujin circle La Moon.

__Character:__ Twisted mind  
__Debut:__ In 1984, "KIKAI" won the best newcomer manga artists award sponsored by weekly Shonen Sunday magazine.  

[Website](http://jajatom.moo.jp/frame.html) | [Blog](https://yukitolog.blogspot.com) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5d4dygMjQL_wHtzefcM-YA)

He likes to collect theme songs of nostalgic animated series and making a collection of books on unnatural phenomena.

[Website](http://www.kaoru-wada.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/kaoru_wadash) | [Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/4zbQfESCpBlXi1XlpnlG95)

He is a Japanese music composer. Married to voice actress [Akiko Nakagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/95749/Akiko-Nakagawa).
Worked for ADV Films and currently Funimation. He's an ADR Director, Recording engineer, and voice actor for numerous works.

Matt Greenfield is the American co-founder of the now defunct ADV Films. Originally an avid fan who ran an anime club in Houston, Texas with David Williams (known as "Anime NASA"). He, Williams and [John Ledford](https://anilist.co/staff/102621/) founded ADV Films in 1992, which began as an importer of anime, marketing primarily to the existing network of anime fans. He was married to ADV contractor and voice actress [Tiffany Grant](https://anilist.co/staff/95145).

In the English-language dubs of the ADV's licensed releases, he serves as an ADR director and occasionally takes on background roles as a voice actor, going by the pseudonym Brian Granveldt.

He continues to write and produce English dubs for new companies and distributors such as Sentai Filmworks and Section23 Films via post-production house/dubbing studio Seraphim Digital.

Matt Greenfield is the American co-founder of the now defunct ADV Films. Originally an avid fan who ran an anime club in Houston, Texas with David Williams (known as "Anime NASA"). He, Williams and [John Ledford](https://anilist.co/staff/102621/) founded ADV Films in 1992, which began as an importer of anime, marketing primarily to the existing network of anime fans. He was married to ADV contractor and voice actress [Tiffany Grant](https://anilist.co/staff/95145).

In the English-language dubs of the ADV's licensed releases, he serves as an ADR director and occasionally takes on background roles as a voice actor, going by the pseudonym Brian Granveldt.

He continues to write and produce English dubs for new companies and distributors such as Sentai Filmworks and Section23 Films via post-production house/dubbing studio Seraphim Digital.

Shigeyuki Hayashi, better known by his pseudonym Rintarou, is a well-known anime director.

A film buff ever since he was a kid, he wanted to pursue a career in filmmaking. After having worked as a cel painter in commercial animation, he joined [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/) in 1958 for a brief time working on films such as [Hakujaden](https://anilist.co/anime/4513/) and [Saiyuuki](https://anilist.co/anime/4481/). After having been told that he couldn't work as a director due to not being a college graduate, he moved to [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) - making his directorial debut as one of the regular episode directors on [Tetsuwan Atom](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/).

In 1972, Rintarou left Mushi Pro to go freelance and to co-found [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11) together with [Masao Maruyama](https://anilist.co/staff/103170/), [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/). A few years later, Rintarou got invited to direct [Jetter Mars](https://anilist.co/anime/6087/) at his previously disinterested workplace, Toei Animation. He accepted the offer but didn't join the studio as an employee, making him one of the few people who've directed for the studio while not being an inhouse employee. He continued to direct multiple entries for Toei, including [Arrow Emblem](https://anilist.co/anime/3800/), [Captain Harlock](https://anilist.co/anime/1000/), as well as the 1979 film [Galaxy Express 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1301/), which is still considered by many as his best work.

[Haruki Kadokawa](https://anilist.co/staff/170354/), the president of [Kadokawa Shoten](https://anilist.co/studio/113/), took notice of the commercial success of Rintarou's works and hired him to direct [Genma Taisen](https://anilist.co/anime/1626/), which was the very first film produced by Kadokawa. The animation production was handled by Madhouse, where Rintarou changed his post at this time. There he continued his directorial efforts with numerous films and OVA series.

The older brother of [Masayuki Hayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/161046/).

John Ledford is an entrepreneur and leader in the North American anime industry. In 1992, he founded A.D. Vision (ADV), paving the way for other businesses and the exponential growth anime has had within North America. With ADV's success, Ledford turned his sights to making the imaginative world of anime even more accessible with Anime Network's founding, North America’s first cable TV network dedicated to anime. He later partnered with Kadokawa Publishing and began Newtype USA with translated Japanese content and exclusive U.S. material related to all things anime, manga, and model reviews. This endeavor expanded into ADV Manga, which obtained licensing and publishing rights for hundreds of Japanese manga and Korean manhwa.

In 2008, Ledford founded a new anime-focused company called Sentai Filmworks (Sentai). Since its founding, Sentai provides thousands of hours of content across traditional and digital platforms. Sentai’s dedication to bringing captivating stories, including acclaimed titles such as Grave of the Fireflies, Ninja Scroll, and High School of the Dead to audiences, is ongoing.

Ledford’s most recent success is with the 2017 founding of the streaming service HIDIVE. Since launching, HIDIVE is now available via a web browser, mobile devices, gaming platforms, and more. HIDIVE offers new simulcasts every season, an ever-growing collection of dubs, and exclusive titles. The service features DUBCAST SM editions, early access local-language dubs of simulcasts directly produced by HIDIVE, as early as two weeks after the original Japanese broadcast.

For nearly thirty years now, Ledford continues his goal to further the expansion of anime and the Japanese culture as a whole.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/福冨博) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiroshi_Fukutomi)

Originating from [Shin-Ei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/247/)

Married to animator [Kazuko Fukutomi](https://anilist.co/staff/157057/).
He was an art director working for Atelier Bwca.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/shinya1965)

Nowadays he's always credited with his given name in hiragana, but early in his career he was credited in all kanji.

_Note: Not to be confused with the [older animator](https://anilist.co/staff/148890/)._
Originating from Ad Cosmo.

Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/). Directs on rare occasions.

Worked for Square Enix in Honolulu, Hawaii together with [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/) and others for the first decade of the 2000s and was completely absent from the anime industry because of this. Returned in 2011 and has been active since.
Co-founder of Manga Entertainment

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/136171134)

A long-serving anime producer, as well as a founder of [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/), [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/) and [Studio M2](https://anilist.co/studio/6137/). He currently serves as the Chairman of the Board at [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/).

Maruyama graduated from Hosei University in 1963, and soon after, he found work at [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1965. It was here that he met many of Madhouse's future staff members. In October 1972, he left Mushi Production together with [Rintarou](https://anilist.co/staff/102305/), [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/) and founded Madhouse. From that time onward, Maruyama focused mainly on producing and planning Madhouse's upcoming projects. He also served as the studio's president through the '80s and '90s.

Thanks in large part to his frequent attendance at anime conventions, he has become well-known in America among Madhouse's fanbase. Not simply wanting to emulate past successes, Maruyama frequently says at these events that his goal as a producer is to seek out new challenges that will allow the production staff to keep experimenting. This attitude in part has been the reason why he has encouraged the studio to take on projects that may not seem like sure-fire commercial hits. In addition, Maruyama has long been a supporter of bringing new talents into the animation business, and continues to encourage young people to work in anime.

In 2011, he left Madhouse and founded Mappa. Later in 2016, he left Mappa and founded Studio M2.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Appeared in Star Wars: A New Hope as Commander Praji

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1521695330)

Currently working as a freelancer, having previously worked for [Artland](https://anilist.co/studio/8/) and [D.A.S.T.](https://anilist.co/studio/6255/)

Yuuki graduated from Saitama Prefectural Toda Shoyo High School and has been active in the school's "Manga and Anime Research Interest Club.” He found business in the National Health Insurance but couldn't give up on being an animator, so he left and became an animator instead. Has collaborated with director [Kazuki Akane](https://anilist.co/staff/102416/) many times, including on his most famous work, [The Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/).

He works on doujinshi under the circles The Man in the High Castle and Ubik, both references to the works of American science fiction author Philip K. Dick. The published doujinshi include key animation from his body of work and specially drawn manga. On the other hand, since he worked on Ralphilia Saga by [Akara Arisato](https://anilist.co/staff/149449/), he has been involved in several works as a guest member of the doujin circle La Moon.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E9%81%A0%E8%97%A4%E6%98%8E%E7%AF%84)

Doshisha University graduate.

Originating from [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). Noted for his work on EDs, which he usually animates by himself. He often asks for [Yoshiyuki Takei](https://anilist.co/staff/150095/) to handle the photography work in them because of the trust he has in his compositing skills. Suzuki is also close friends with [Kumiko Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/104698/) and participates in most of the shows in which she serves as a character designer.

Nowadays, he rarely puts his name on the telop and has gone uncredited for most of his work after [Soul Eater](https://anilist.co/anime/3588/).
